segments.text: What about re-arming Germany in the early 1950s?
You were there, and did you participate?
What was your role?
I guess my role was trying to build a U.S.
Seventh Army from 55,000 up to 225,000 at the time, and fitting that buildup into the

into West Germany as cheaply as possible by using old German facilities because of the great expense and at the same time that being tactically unsound in some instances but because of money I was troubled with finding places so we had to use
what we could find available.
And then to see the German army come in and the German government build brand new facilities, brand new barracks, brand new motor pools, brand new living areas and so on and so forth for them.
And here the conqueror was taking the crap, the old stuff that they had discarded and
The victor was taking that and the loser was getting brand new stuff and being tactically deployed where it's to his advantage.
The philosophy and the principle behind re-arming a germ is absolutely supportable and durable and that's the way it ought to be.

and unfortunately it hasn't lessened our effort over there or expenditure which has been very disturbing to me that as we Germans have built five hundred thousand and twelve divisions as you know they have a draft for sixteen months fifteen sixteen months
They have no responsibilities outside of West Germany, so they get proper utilization out of 15 to 16 months of conscription.
And then those chaps, after they leave, go into the reserve in what they call the territorial forces, and they become a part of the defense effort, a very strong part of the defense effort.
Right today, their tanks and trucks are all maintained by the manufacturer, so they don't have a long logistics tail.
In other words, the Mon 10-ton truck
maintained by that civilian corporation.
At the time of conflict, their constitution states that 80% of the industrial effort will go toward maintenance of the armed forces.
So you've got a pretty strong logistic base there that's working every day commercially, and that makes it a very strong force, I think.
With the territorials, they could probably expand to
24 or 25 divisions or more without any trouble with people that are trained.
They're very well organized.
And I think it's a direction, I think it's an appropriate direction to go.
And as I say, I only wish that there's some way that we could have withered on some of our strength there.
On the other hand, in this world in which we live today,
is my firm conviction and view that the further our front lines are away from our shores, the better off we are.
It's bad enough with a range of weapons today.
It's bad enough with strategic weapons.
But you've got Soviet submarines floating around out here that can reach Dallas, Texas without any trouble with a nuclear warhead.
can hit Houston with no problem at all from submarines that are floating out there.
1,500-2,000 mile capability.
You've got the MiG-23s and MiG-25s down in Cuba that can come into the Florida area any day they want to.
We have one airplane that can touch the MiG-25 and that's a SR-71 and our SR-71 carries no weapons so you don't kill MiG-25s with cameras.
So this is the seriousness of the situation today and I only mention that to point out that NATO is a durable and workable
viable organization so long as everybody over there does its part and that the United States is not saddled with the whole burden.
And I have felt all along that the trend was toward get as much out of the United States before you do anything, you see, because they're a soft nation.
They're an undisciplined group of people that are very soft and want everybody to love them so they'll spend money
to get somebody to love them, you see.
They'll give millions and billions of dollars to somebody, oh, if you'll just love us, you know.
But love isn't worry, it's respect, and respect comes from being a tough bunch of bastards, and we're not that way.
So everybody's gouging us.
Now, getting back to your first assignment as commander of the Special Troops Regiment, I was wondering why were you called Special Troops?
What was special about you people?
It's special because it was not a combat table of organization.
It is a special organization to meet the requirements of a high headquarters.

In other words, on my personnel reports each day, I carried all the generals and the colonels and that sort of stuff, and all the senior sergeants, everybody in that headquarters carried a couple thousand of them, a thousand or more.
And then you had special intelligence of several different types of units.
you had special security in there.
So, there's nothing, that headquarters, those troops, there's nothing consistent with anywhere else that was designed to support that particular mission, you see.
During this period, you were there during a very fascinating period of rebuilding in Germany,
By 1947, we had promulgated the Marshall Plan and we started pumping money for the next year into the country, quite a bit of money from 48 down to 52.
What were the relationships that you had with the German people while this rebuilding was going on?
We had almost daily contact.
some aspect of German society.
They had a large number of German workers, some German clerks in the headquarters, some German people with responsibility for maintenance of facilities, labor force.
We had relationships with a
with a mayor's where we had, and a Burgermeister's where we had troops stationed, and each small installation had a relationship with the German community.
We took on, the Army took on a responsibility for setting up German-American clubs for the soldiers
for bringing in German families into the military organization for Sunday lunches and dinners and socials and the relationships were growing continuously.
We
got involved in helping the ladies clubs, got involved with German ladies in running care centers for the disabled German people and providing food and clothing and that sort of thing.
And we took on even a more
intense role of community relations than you find here amongst our people right now because I don't know the name of that neighbor over there, but you did in Germany.
How did the German people respond to you, the conqueror?
I thought they responded in this sort of fashion.
After the war is over, you could not find one single Nazi in Germany.
You didn't survive unless you were one, you see?
So that was their attitude and we looked over our shoulder and accepted that.
So we got along very well.
Miss Hollingsworth could

speaks in German and read German and we had a few incidences which were embarrassing such as Miss Hollingsworth and I trout fishing in a stream and we're doing very well and then she gets tired and goes back to the automobile to rest and I'm continuing to fish and I've come to an area and
And the trout just seemed like it was just loaded with trout.
And a German Jgermeister, I find out who he was later, was hollering in there saying, no, no, no fishing here.
So I stepped back to the car and I said, there's some German down here yelling at me.
And said, I wish you'd come down here and tell him to get on his way or find out what the hell he wants.
So she came down and she said, I don't have to ask him.
She said, you're fishing in a fish hatchery.
I said, well I thought they were biting pretty good here.
So she apologized to him and I left.
Well,
That's the best fishing you ever had.
Yeah, oh, man, they were really strong.
Every time I threw a spinner out there, I was bringing in about a 10-inch German brown.
There were just plenty of them in there.
And they were hungry, too.
Oh, they were hungry.
But I thought the relationships, you know, it's a very difficult thing, not so much for soldiers.
After a battle is over and it's on the force, a soldier can sit down and smoke a cigarette together and if they can understand the same language, they have no hard feelings about it.
Because they're just doing what they ordered to do.
But not so much with the young and the old and the civilian side of things.
I would say it's more difficult for them.
They suffered tremendously.
They suffered from a lack of food, a variety of food, and the discomfort of not being able to do what they like to do.
In the case of Germany, Germans mostly work.
They all go on vacation in August.
County did in August, because everybody goes on vacation in August.
Shores, stores closed, everything closed.
Bare essentials go on.
Well, that didn't happen for them during the war years.
And nothing that was going on, as far as I'm concerned, they enjoyed at all.
So now that the war is over and
what they had lived for all their lives, much of it had been destroyed and blown away.
Their fields and farms were bombs and potholes.
Now, while you were there, of course, Korea, the Korean conflict started.
Did you want to go to Korea?
Did you volunteer for that?
I volunteered for Korea, but since I was Chief of Operations, General Eddy, who was the Army Lieutenant General,
Manton S. Eddy, a magnificent gentleman, EDDY, Manton S. Eddy, he felt this way about it.
He said, why do you want to leave me here when you're building up this force here for me and run off to Korea?
And I said, well, there's war going on there.
And he said, what you're doing here is trying to prevent one.
So which is important, trying to prevent one or go try to put out a fire when one started?
He said, you're going to stay here, young man.
So I said, yes, sir, I'll stay here.
And then, lo and behold, we get a message in within a week or so
saying, you have been selected for the Command and General Staff College.
So, I didn't have any choice about that.
Well, that's quite an honor.
Yes, and particularly selected the head of my contemporaries.
So that was in August of 1951 until June of 1952.
Let's talk about the Command and General Staff School.
Wasn't this, when was it instituted?
third or fourth class of that?
Well, actually the Command and General Staff College goes way back.
Oh, I'm thinking of something else now.
Yeah, you're talking about the Army War College.
That's what I'm thinking about.
But Command and General Staff College is probably the most important school in the military arts
there is in the world becauseand I say world because that's where a lot of the students come from, from the worldless communist nations.
It takes you and says you're going toit would appear those who are selected
The record says you're going to high staff positions and command positions.
And that's why it says command and the staff up at the division level.
In other words, the command of a division and staff at the Department of the Army level.
And it is the equivalent of a master's degree in our school system.
Our advanced course is the equivalency of a baccalaureate degree in military art and science.
Command and General Staff College is the equivalent of a master's degree in military art and sciences.
The Army War College is the equivalent of a Ph.D. in military art and science.
And as you higher you go,
The more selective and the fewer, they get a chance to go.
And if you don't go, you just remember that your career is going to be short lived.
And no question about that.
You'll get to be maybe a lieutenant colonel unless you get a command general staff school and you're out at that year twenty or if you're a reserve officer you may be released long before that.
If you do go to command, you're on staff.
You can probably count on being promoted to colonel if you do well.
Tell me about the curriculum.
Curriculum is a very intense day in, day out, a lot of night work.
gets deeply involved in the leadership of people, management, transportation, finance, logistics, tactical considerations, political aspects of
land and business management.
It is a long, intense, hard year.
How many were in your class?
There was six hundred in my class, including foreign students.
And what nations were they usually from?
Canada, New Zealand, all the commonwealth nations, New Zealand, India,
Pakistan, Korea, now Japanese, Brazil, sometimes Peru, sometimes Argentina.
Mexico?
It used to be Ethiopia, Mexico.
When I was there, I think there were about forty nations there.
But the Brits, Canadians, New Zealand, Commonwealth nations have two or three there.
And we do the same thing for them.
But it's a very intense program requiring a lot of night work.
Now you said that you weren't a very good student at A&M.
Were you a very good student at this school?
in the top ten percent of this school.
What was the difference?
Time to study, time to concentrate on it.
I didn't have to spend eight hours of work a day.
I see.
I didn't spend any.
As a matter of fact, I played golf at three o'clock every day, and met all the requirements
It's, and I must say, it's not very easy in school.
And from there you became an instructor at West Point.
Yes, I- That certainly didn't set you up for a command position, did it?
No, but during the life of the military, let's see, where were we?
You were talking about during the life of the military.
I said I didn't set you up for a command position.
You're off to West Point.
Yeah.
Again, I wanted to go to Korea.
Oh, you put in for Korea?
I put in for Korea, and they turned me down.
And I found out that the man responsible for me going to
with being selected for West Point was General Maxwell D. Taylor, who was the chief of operations and plans in the Department of the Army who selected the people to go.
And at the same time, amongst the officers in the Army, there is a requirement to do civilian component duty.

In other words, to go to ROTC or to go work with the reserves or go to National Guard or go to United Nations or some other place, ROTC is a key one which has not been given all the credit it ought to have and the caliber of people in every instance it ought to have.
So you knew that you were up for a position like that.
You were probably overdue.
I was overdue, way overdue.
I've never asked for an assignment except to go to combat and I've never objected to one.
So off I went to West Point and found out that General Taylor was responsible for that.
Did you later get to know General Taylor?
Oh yes.
I was at West Point, and in December, I guess, of 1953, I got a call from the Department of the Army saying that General Matthew B. Ridgeway
The Supreme Allied Commander had been appointed Chief of Staff in the Army, and you were to report to his office for duty on a, on very short notice in December of 1953.
And I didn't want to leave West Point because I loved those cadets.
They were just absolutely magnificent.
In fact, two of those cadets worked for my company that I have in Washington right now.
And they were just absolutely
the most marvelous bunch of young men I've ever associated with.
And the West Point, the whole life up there, they treated Miss Hollingsworth and our son, Jamo, just absolutely.
I met Vince Lombardi there, Lince Lombardi, yeah, and Earl Blake was there, and every time I got down a chance to
go down and talk to them, I did.
As a matter of fact, I taught handball there at West Point.
I was responsible for the pistol team.
I was responsible for the fishing and hunting at West Point on the reservation for the cadets.
I enjoyed that very much.
So I went to Washington.
So that's what you were instructing?
I was an instructor in tactics and leadership, but I did all these other side things.
You do those extracurricular things, so to speak, without pay, but that's the way it goes.
But I went to Washington and then very
And you met Ridgway, right?
Yeah, then a very interesting occurred.
Well, what happened as far as Ridgway?
Well, um, John Ridgway decided that he could more or less, he retired or left on his own accord because of conflict with Eisenhower and engine Charlie Wilson.
And I was deeply involved.
I was one of the five colonels that revolted against the President of the United States and the Secretary of Defense.
Was this a so-called colonel's revolt?
Colonel's revolt.
And you were in on that?
Oh, I was one of the key members of it.
Well, let's talk about that.
I can't talk too much about it.
Well, you could give me a basic outline of how it came about and your role.

Basic outline, uh, I don't want to say too much about it because there's some high-level people that, uh, in government today, in the legislative branch, in the retired status that, uh, it's best not be said, uh, the whole story until, uh,
And because I'm just that way about it, I will say that it came about as, in my viewI'll just put it this way and not implicate what happenedin my view, it all came about as a result
The grand old Big Bang for the buck.
What's good for General Motors is good for the United States.
A fat bird dog won't hunt, and people are like bird dogs.
All of Wilson's cliches.
All of Wilson's cliches.
And Eisenhower...
I now are trying to destroy the army.
We don't need any army.
We don't need a tactical air force.
All you need is strategic bombers and missiles, and that's all.
And it's obvious to anybody that's got any sense and any responsibility to this country to know that

which has been a proven fact that by God you do need an army and you need a navy and you need an air force and you need all elements of both of them in order to defend this country and this country deserves that and it wasn't getting that and that's the reason why I participated in the colonel with the other four to revolt against this stuff.
And we did it pretty effectively.
We got caught up with it on the 26th of April, 1955, or 1956.
We got caught up with it and we were all threatened with court martial.

And you've got to be, if you're going to get involved in this sort of thing, I'll just put it this way, you've got to be smart enough to take care of it and look at the option of getting caught and what you do about it.
So you just create a fire in the Pentagon and burn everything.
If I'd have been in the White House, Mr. Nixon never would have had to resign because I'd have burned these damn tapes whether he didn't want to or not.
So this thing, as a result of it,
We got a handle on tactical air support.
We got the mobility we needed for the Army and helicopters.
We still got a long ways to go, but we reversed the trend of destruction of the Army and the destruction of the tactical air force.
We got C-130s, 141s, we got C-5As.
Now, we haven't been totally happy with everything that we got, but we turned the trend back from destruction of the Army and depending on the Strategic Air Command and the nuclear, strategic nukes,
the one of bringing some sense and balance to what's needed to defend the country.
You need several options.
You need a fulfillment of the present options we have and a continuous readiness and a continuous modernization of the strategic capability of the conventional deterrent capability
and theater nuclear, tactical nuclear capability, and one in which we just lost in the Congress again, a chemical offensive capability, which the Soviets, our opponents, have and we don't have.
So they could exercise that option against us, and we have no capability to exercise the same option against them.
because he was killed just a few days ago in the Congress.
Now, as far as the colonel's revolt is concerned, could you give me a little bit more specifics just on your own role?
We don't have to talk about the other men.
My role was to cover the Congress.
To pass to them selected groups what we were up to.
At this time you were in the Pentagon as the chief of the liaison division.
So you were working with the congressman and you were the liaison between the Pentagon.
Yes.
Okay.
During the Army.
Chief of Staff, I was in the Chief of Staff's office.
You represented I was the secretary of the Army.
Yeah, right.
Those are the two guys I represented on the Hill.
Okay.
Let's go more into your role and how this transpired for you.
My role was one of working about 18 hours a day, meeting with the other colonels who had different responsibilities, and putting together
the kind of an army that we felt we needed in order to defend the country.
The Eisenhower approach was a pentomic army.
Let me give you a good example of what he was talking about.
Pentomic army, division, pentomic division.
Pentomic Division was five battalions of infantry plus one battery of artillery for each of those five battalions and the supporting element for them.
And five batteries of artillery in a division and only five battalions?
That's not a division.
That's about a good brigade, less the artillery it really needs.
Well, let's look at five battalions.
Say there's 1,000 men in each battalion, actually 750 infantrymen in each battalion.
That's five times 750.
What is the strength of a regular division at that time?
How many battalions of infantry?
Six battalions of infantry, four tank battalions, or two tank battalions, plus four battalions of artillery, four times 18.
That's what we went from down to the pandemic, a total destruction of capability.
And I couldn't stand that.
Nobody could stand that.
So we set out to save an army.
And one of the key areas to save the army is the one that has the responsibility for raising and maintaining the armed forces, and that's the Congress of the United States.

briefed select members one of the ones that when it finally got around to we had to search industry to see if industry could support what we wanted to do in maintaining an army in building an army getting helicopters building a tactical air force troop carrier capability fighter aircraft that could support the army new munitions
and that sort of stuff, to build a conventional capability against this business of the great big umbrella and all the wars going down under it, and which they did.
Korea was a conventional war under the big umbrella.
The nuclear umbrella.
Sure.
The same thing in all other parts of the world.
In Lebanon, it's going on right today.
Conventional war.
under the big umbrella.
And what's the big umbrella done about the nuclear strategic capability done about those small conventional wars?
Not one damn thing.
So it's become obvious that what the hell we wanted to do and what we had to do and what we still got to work on very hard to keep this force together.
And we'd just gone through Korea where we'd been pushed and shoved around all over the place because of the total depleting of our capability while Eisenhower was Chief of Staff of the Army.
And now here he is, President, and he's continued to move to destroy his own damn service.
Well, you can understand why I have no regard for him whatsoever.
And to have a sick president keep me from going to Berlin, as far as I'm concerned, Eisenhower had a major role in that.
And it had been a different world today.
Much a different world today.
And so how did you, and so the interest of the Army, and did Secretary Stevens support you?
Brucker.
Brucker by this time, yeah.
Yeah.
Okay.
Secretary Brucker.
Secretary Brucker, one of the great civilian supporters.
When it came around to, when the budget, when Eisenhower found his budget had been changed,
Certain things cut out and other things added, military wise.
Yeah, because of your dealings with Congress?
Absolutely.
Okay.
Tell me about some of those dealings.
Well, many of those dealings went on at night in dark alleys and in dark restaurants.
And budgets were looked at, and this cut out, and money added here and there, and this weapons added in and on and forth.
And this was with the Center for Armed Services Committee members?
This came about through the good judgment and the desire of people who could understand and believed in what we were trying to do in the authorization area.
And one of the great supporters was a young man who had the know-how when we got around to finding out if the civilian side could do this.
A young senator who I admire and respect forever and ever.
I went to him and said, sir, you know what we're trying to do, and you believe in what we're trying to do.
Can you contact the civilian side or call them in to find out whether or not industry can support this sort of thing?
And he said, I'll do it.
His name was John F. Kennedy.
What a hell of a guy.
And, of course, he's the guy that proved off for me being
Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Mr. McNamara.
He could have, Mr. Kennedy could have asked Mr. McNamara to put a civilian in there if he had wanted to, but he didn't do that.
So, Mr. McNamara would have forged, and Mr. Hitch
Mr. Ignatius, Mr. Tom Morris, all of those were involved indirectly, unbeknownst to them, I think.
But I thought Mr. McNamara's first move after the Army

diddled around for so long, he personally selected General Ham Howes, who was here in Fort Worth, to head up the Howes Board and start moving in the direction in which these colonels had been working.
And we got the Air Cavalry Division and all that.
Magnus Meyer personally did that over the head of the Army Chief of Staff, because the Army Chief of Staff at that time
was a man named General Decker, who was a great hell of a golf player.
He could build a hell of a golf course, and he was one hell of a fine guy, but let's just leave it right there.
Okay, well let's go back now to 1956.
So in other words, you were building congressional support.
for the type of army that you thought was necessary.
You must have had a number of generals, even though it's called the Colonel's Revolt, you must have had a number of generals in the Pentagon who encouraged you or supported your efforts.
Sure did.
Maxwell D. Taylor was interested in a strong army.
I'm not going to say that he participated in the Colonel's revolt because as far as I know, he didn't.
And neither did Dental Ridgeway.
But they must have talked to you.
They talked to everybody about what we needed in the way of an army.
But they are hereby at the presidential selectees as a three-star general is.
You serve in a four-star.
Now, by law, Title X, U.S. Code, the highest grade you can attain is major general.
That's by law.
However, the president may select for a one assignment only.
The president may select people for
promotion to three-star and four-star.
They're selected for only that assignment.
At the end of that assignment, they have to go back to the grade of major general unless the president so selects him for another three-star slot.
Unless that three-star slot that he selected you for, at the time you leave this three-star billet,
If that three-star bill is still occupied, even in transit, you revert back to a major general.
And the same is true with a four-star.
So, the three and four-stars are at the pleasure of this particular assignment of the president.
